Bones can become weak and break if you have certain [[diseases; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/chronic-diseases/osteoporosis.html]] or as we age.
If you are healthy with no risks the Canadian Task Force recommends only women 65 and over use a decision aid before doing a bone density test.
For healthy men with no risks or diseases weakening their bones, tests are not recommended according to research and can cause harm.
•[[Decision aid; https://frax.canadiantaskforce.ca/index.php?r=site%2Findex]]
•Bone density test:
An x-ray detector scans your spine and hip.
You receive a very small amount of radiation.
People with certain diseases or certain fractures will need to go straight to a bone density test.

An x-ray machine scans the lungs
It uses low doses of radiation to make a series of  pictures of the lungs.

A mammogram is an xray of the breasts.
Radiation has been cut back to a very [[small dose; https://www.cancer.org/cancer/breast-cancer/screening-tests-and-early-detection/mammograms/mammogram-basics.html/]].
You receive radiation from your environment every day. A screening mammogram contains the amount of radiation you would get from your natural environment in 7 weeks. 
This is done for prevention every 2 years age 50 to 74 for patients with no symptoms or risks.

The MOCA (Montreal Cognitive Assesement) or MMSE (Mini-Mental State Examination)
 are tests given to patients who may have memory problems. 
Each is a series of questions and takes around 10-15 minutes.

Starting age depends on your province or territory (21 or 25).
This requires a pelvic exam by your health provider.
 A brush is used to collect cells from the cervix.

This is a blood test to see if you are immune (protected) against rubella(german measles) or varicella (chicken pox). 
if you are non immune you may become infected with rubella during a pregnancy
which could cause birth defects or serious health problems for you.

If sexually active testing for stis includes: 
•Women: a pelvic exam or a urine test; and blood tests. 
•Men: a urine test and blood tests
Urine test tests are for Chlamydia and Gonorrhea. 
The test done by pelvic exam in women is for Chlamydia and Gonorrhea
Blood tests: it is recommended to include tests for HIV, Syphilis, Hepatitis B, and some include Hepatitis C.

This measures your blood sugar level if you are at risk for diabetes.
This shows if you are diabetic, pre-diabetic or normal.

AAA means Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm.
 Men age 65-80 may benefit from an ultrasound to detect AAA.
An abdomina ultrasound to detect AAA is a simple test, that does not hurt, where the technician puts gel on the skin of the abdomen and passess a camera over the skin to see the blood vessel called the aorta.

Click on the word [[video; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5yliqM7GpvU]] to see what an abdominal aortic aneurysm screening ultrasound is like in the UK which uses a similar process to Canada.
 Note differences between UK and Canada:
•You should see your health care provider to discuss if this test is right for you.
•The results may not be available the same day
•We stop at age 80
See the official Canadian Task Force guideline [[here; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/abdominal-aortic-aneurysm/]]

As we age, testing for cancer or other diseases can cause more harm than good.
It depends on your overall health, speak to your provider.
